prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will image 16 Herschel-selected galaxies that are suspected of being strongly gravitationally lensed on the basis of their submillimeter colours and optical/near-IR redshifts. These systems probe the fainter end of the lensed submillimeter galaxy number counts, and our observations will test the proposed selection method, which has the potential of identifying hundreds of gravitationally lensed submillimeter galaxies, which are expected to be the intrinsically faint contributors to the cosmic-infrared background.
We request "Single Continuum" mode observations in band 7 (343 GHz; 875 micron), at a resolution of 0.45". This resolution has proved to be successful in efficiently identifying morphological signatures of gravitational lensing in our ALMA cycle 0 study of the brightest Herschel galaxies (Figure 2; Bussmann et al, in prep; PI: Riechers). The targets are expected to have integrated 870 micron fluxes in the range of 10 to 20mJy and typically be extended over ~5 to 10 beams, or 20 beams in rare cases. Thus, to robustly detect these resolved sources and be able to perform gravitational lens modelling we aim to reach 0.1mJy/beam rms sensitivity. We note that this depth is about twice as deep as the cycle 0 data of bright lensed HerMES galaxies (PI: Riechers), which is necessary because of the fainter selection limit of our sample.
To reach this sensitivity is expected to require 4.3 minutes on-source, per target. Based on our experience with the cycle 0 lensing survey (Figure 2), with the greater complement of antennae available in cycle 2 we expect that a single 4.3 minute integration will be sufficient to recover all the structure in the targets. However, we aim to gain additional image fidelity by employing track sharing (all of the targets are within the same ~1 degree radius region), and splitting the on-source time into ~1.5 minute intervals. We also prefer to run the dynamical blocks at different start times, if permitted by the schedule, to improve the sampling of the uv plane.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a survey to map the continuum emission from 16 gravitational lens candidates in the HerMES XMM-LSS field. The lens candidates are selected via a new method based on SED-modelling, infrared colour and optical redshift, enabling the identification of gravitationally lensed galaxies down to the detection limits of deep far-infrared surveys. Once verified our method can be used to identify many hundreds of such systems in data from Herschel and future wide-field multiwavelength submillimeter surveys, leading to studies of dark matter in a large sample of foreground lensing galaxies as well as detailed spatial and spectroscopic study of faint high-redshift star-forming galaxies. We will also use the ALMA data to test the validity and reliability of our method. We will also use the proposed data, in combination with existing multi-wavelength ancillary imaging and spectroscopy, to study the lensed submillimeter galaxies in detail, by lens modelling the systems and measuring the lensing amplification and therefore the intrinsic properties of these galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine
